title: Who has the Best Fans in College Sports?
text:
College sports fans can be crazy with a wild fan base and show their passion in many ways. One way that millions of fans show their fandom for their favorite teams is by attending games and events. With 100s of collegiate teams, and narrowing it down to looking at volleyball, men’s basketball, women’s basketball, football, softball, and baseball, what team leads in attendance?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
library(scales)

volleyball <- read_csv("volleyballdata.csv") |>
mutate(sport = "Volleyball", year = 2023) 

volleyball2022 <- read_csv("volleyballdata2022.csv") |>
  mutate(sport = "Volleyball", year = 2022)

mensbball <- read_csv("mensbasketballdata.csv") |>
  mutate(sport = "Men’s Basketball", year = 2023) 

mensbball2022 <- read_csv("mensbballdata2022.csv") |>
mutate(sport = "Men's Basketball", year = 2022)

football <- read_csv("footballdata.csv") |>
mutate(sport = "Football", year = 2023) 

football2022 <- read_csv("football2022data.csv") |>
mutate(sport = "Football", year = 2022)

baseball <- read_csv("baseballdata.csv") |>
mutate(sport = "Baseball", year = 2023) 

baseball2022 <- read_csv("baseball2022data.csv") |>
  mutate(sport = "Baseball", year = 2022)

womensbball <-read_csv("womensbasketballdata.csv") |>
mutate(sport = "Women's Basketball", year = 2023)

womensbball2022 <- read_csv("womensbball2022data.csv") |>
  mutate(sport = "Women's Basketball", year = 2022)

softball <- read_csv("softballdata.csv") |>
  mutate(sport = "Softball", year = 2023) 

softball2022 <- read_csv("softball2022data.csv") |>
  mutate(sport = "Softball", year = 2022) 

sports2023 <- bind_rows(volleyball, mensbball, football, baseball, womensbball, softball)

sports2022 <- bind_rows(volleyball2022, mensbball2022, football2022, baseball2022, womensbball2022, softball2022)

sports <- bind_rows(sports2023, sports2022)
bigten <- sports2023 |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten")

powerfive <- sports2023 |> filter(Conference == "ACC" | Conference == "Big Ten" | Conference == "Pac-12" | Conference == "SEC" | Conference == "Big 12")

attendance <- sports2023 |> 
  group_by(Institution,Conference) |> 
  summarise(
    totalattendance = sum(`Accum Attendance`)
  ) |> arrange(desc(totalattendance))

nu <- attendance |> filter(Institution == "Nebraska")

lsu <- attendance |> filter(Institution == "LSU")

ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(data=attendance, aes(x=totalattendance, y=Conference), color="lightgrey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(data=nu, aes(x=totalattendance, y=Conference),color="#E41C38") + 
  geom_beeswarm(data=lsu, aes(x=totalattendance, y=Conference),color="#461D7C") +
  geom_text_repel(data=nu, aes(x=totalattendance, y=Conference, label=Institution)) +
  geom_text_repel(data=lsu, aes(x=totalattendance, y=Conference, label=Institution)) + scale_x_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    x="Total Attendance", 
    y="Conference", 
    title="Nebraska and LSU Fans Pack the Stands", 
    subtitle="Huskers and Tigers have the highest numbers of total athletic attendance in 2023-2024 seasons.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Nebraska and LSU are set apart from other schools for their attendance numbers and passionate fanbase in 2022. When looking at 2023, both teams remain at the top. Although LSU remains the lead, its numbers decrease as Nebraskas increase drastically. What did Nebraska do differently than LSU?


Code
powerfive <- sports |> filter(Conference == "ACC" | Conference == "Big Ten" | Conference == "Pac-12" | Conference == "SEC" | Conference == "Big 12")

attendanceslope <- sports |> 
  group_by(Institution,Conference, year) |> 
  summarise(
    totalattendance = sum(`Accum Attendance`)
  ) |> arrange(desc(totalattendance))

nu5 <- attendanceslope |> filter(Institution == "Nebraska")
lsu5 <- attendanceslope |> filter(Institution == "LSU") 

ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=attendanceslope, aes(x=year, y=totalattendance, group=Institution),color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=attendanceslope, aes(x=year, y=totalattendance, group=Institution),color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=nu5, aes(x=year, y=totalattendance, group=Institution),color="#E41C38") +
  geom_point(data=nu5, aes(x=year, y=totalattendance, group=Institution),color="#E41C38") +
geom_line(data=lsu5, aes(x=year, y=totalattendance, group=Institution),color="#461D7C") +
  geom_point(data=lsu5, aes(x=year, y=totalattendance, group=Institution),color="#461D7C") + 
  scale_x_continuous(breaks= c(2022,2023), limits = c(2021.5,2023.5)) +
  geom_text(data=nu5 |> filter(year==max(year)), aes(x=year +.15,y=totalattendance +.05, group=Institution, label=Institution)) +
  geom_text(data=nu5 |> filter(year == min(year)), aes(x=year -.15, y=totalattendance, group=Institution, label=Institution)) + 
   geom_text(data=lsu5 |> filter(year == min(year)), aes(x=year -.15, y=totalattendance, group=Institution, label=Institution)) + 
  labs(
    x="Total Attendance", 
    y="Year", 
    title="Nebraska Volleyball Day Spikes Attendance Numbers", 
    subtitle="The Husker's attendance significantly increases in one year after Nebraska Volleyball Day while LSU's attendance decreases.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









In August, Nebraska Volleyball hosted Volleyball Day in Nebraska. It was a day that set a women’s sports record, with 92,003 fans packing Memorial Stadium. Volleyball day and a fan base that will always show up for their teams could lead to increased attendance.
The Huskers runner-up volleyball team had an undefeated record at home, and Nebraska fans were a big part of that.


Code
powerfivevolleyball <- powerfive |>
  filter(sport =="Volleyball") |>
  filter(year == 2023)

nuvb <- powerfivevolleyball |>
  filter(Institution == "Nebraska")


ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=powerfivevolleyball,
                    aes(x=reorder(Institution, `Accum Attendance`), weight=`Accum Attendance`),fill = "lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=nuvb,
                    aes(x=reorder(Institution, `Accum Attendance`), weight=`Accum Attendance`), fill = "#E41C38") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Attendance", 
    title="A World Record Helps with Attendance Numbers", 
    subtitle="The Husker's filled Memomorial Stadium with 92,003 fans, breaking a world-record for a women's sporting event.", 
    caption="Source: NCAA | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Breaking it down to just volleyball, Nebraska wins by a landslide. Nebraska Volleyball Day was a massive factor in Nebraska Volleyball’s attendance numbers in the 2023 season.
Attendance can be an indicator of how successful athletic programs are. It would be difficult to determine who has the best fan base without looking at other factors, such as how big a school’s venue is or how successful the team is. But the Huskers’ ability to sell out Memorial Stadium for a 5-7 football team and to set a world record for a women’s athletic event speaks for itself..

title: Did Nebraska Basketball Exceed Their Ranking?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
library(scales)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(janitor)

basketball <- read_csv("basketball24.csv") |> remove_empty(which="cols") |> mutate(School = gsub(" NCAA", "", School))
advanced <- read_csv("advancedbasketball.csv") |> remove_empty(which="cols") |> mutate(School = gsub(" NCAA", "", School))

big <- c("Nebraska", "Iowa", "Minnesota","Wisconsin", "Rutgers", "Indiana", "Northwestern","Purdue", "Michigan State", "Michigan", "Penn State","Maryland","Illinois", "Ohio State")

bigtenbasketball <- basketball |>
  filter(School %in% big)

bigtenadvanced <- advanced |> 
  filter(School %in% big)

bigten <- read_csv("bigbasketball24.csv")
opponent <- read_csv("Opponent.csv")|> remove_empty(which="cols") |> mutate(School = gsub(" NCAA", "", School))

bothsides <- basketball |> inner_join(opponent)
bothbig <- bothsides |> filter(School %in% big)

nu3 <- bigten|> filter(School == "Nebraska")

nu <- bigtenbasketball |>
  filter(School == "Nebraska")
nu2 <- bothsides |>
  filter(School == "Nebraska")

bigten |>
  ggplot() + geom_dumbbell(data=bigten, aes(y=reorder(School,ORtg), x=ORtg, xend=DRtg),
colour = "lightgrey",
colour_x = "#0088CE",
colour_xend = "black",
size=2) + 
  geom_dumbbell(data=nu3, aes(y=reorder(School,ORtg), x=ORtg, xend=DRtg),
colour = "#E41C38",
colour_x = "red",
colour_xend = "#900000",
size=2) + 
   labs(
    x="Offensive Rating", 
    y="", 
    title="Nebraska is in the Middle of the Pack", 
    subtitle="Nebraska is ranked 4th in the conference but based on their offensive rating they are in 7th.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 











Code
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data=bothsides, aes(x=`Team3P%`, y=`Opponent3P%`), color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=nu2, aes(x=`Team3P%`, y=`Opponent3P%`), color="#E41C38") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = .3387127, color="lightblue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = .335663, color="lightblue") +
  geom_text_repel(data=nu2, aes(`Team3P%`, y=`Opponent3P%`, label=School)) +
   labs(
    x="Opponent 3P%", 
    y="Team 3P%", 
    title="Making 3-point shots help", 
    subtitle="Nebraska falls short to the opponents 3-point percentage.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 











Code
ggplot() +
geom_bar(data=bigtenbasketball, aes(x=reorder(School,TeamTOV), weight=TeamTOV),fill="lightgrey") +
geom_bar(data=nu, aes(x=reorder(School,TeamTOV), weight=TeamTOV),fill="#E41C38") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Turnovers", 
    title="Husker's Preach Ball Security", 
    subtitle="Nebraska continues to over-perform and exceed their ranking.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    )

title: Introduction
text: Hello. My name is Sophie Widman and I am a junior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. I am a double major in sports media and communications and advertisising and public relations with a minor in communications.

title: Did Nebraska Basketball Exceed Their Ranking?
text:
Nebraska Basketball is back, and Husker Nation couldn’t be more excited. The Huskers qualified for the NCAA March Madness tournament for the first time in 10 years, landing an 8-seed. The team had a monumental season, going 18-1 on their home court. Nebraska was ranked 3rd in the Big Ten and 33rd overall, but the question is, did they exceed their ranking?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
library(scales)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(janitor)

basketball <- read_csv("basketball24.csv") |> remove_empty(which="cols") |> mutate(School = gsub(" NCAA", "", School))
advanced <- read_csv("advancedbasketball.csv") |> remove_empty(which="cols") |> mutate(School = gsub(" NCAA", "", School))

big <- c("Nebraska", "Iowa", "Minnesota","Wisconsin", "Rutgers", "Indiana", "Northwestern","Purdue", "Michigan State", "Michigan", "Penn State","Maryland","Illinois", "Ohio State")

bigtenbasketball <- basketball |>
  filter(School %in% big)

bigtenadvanced <- advanced |> 
  filter(School %in% big)

bigten <- read_csv("bigbasketball24.csv")
opponent <- read_csv("Opponent.csv")|> remove_empty(which="cols") |> mutate(School = gsub(" NCAA", "", School))

bothsides <- basketball |> inner_join(opponent)
bothbig <- bothsides |> filter(School %in% big)

nu3 <- bigten|> filter(School == "Nebraska")
pu<-bothsides |>
  filter(School == "Purdue")
nu <- bigtenbasketball |>
  filter(School == "Nebraska")
nu2 <- bothsides |>
  filter(School == "Nebraska")
msu <- bothsides |>
  filter(School == "Michigan State")
nw <- bothsides |>
  filter(School == "Northwestern")
mi <- bothsides |>
  filter(School == "Michigan")

bigten |>
  ggplot() + geom_dumbbell(data=bigten, aes(y=reorder(School,ORtg), x=ORtg, xend=DRtg),
colour = "lightgrey",
colour_x = "#0088CE",
colour_xend = "black",
size=2) + 
  geom_dumbbell(data=nu3, aes(y=reorder(School,ORtg), x=ORtg, xend=DRtg),
colour = "#E41C38",
colour_x = "red",
colour_xend = "#900000",
size=2) + 
   labs(
    x="Offensive Rating", 
    y="", 
    title="Nebraska is in the Middle of the Pack", 
    subtitle="The Huskers are ranked 3rd in the conference but based on their offensive rating they are ranked 7th.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Nebraska’s offensive and defensive ratings are not the best in the league, but they are still pretty good. The Huskers placed in the top three in the Big Ten Conference, but according to their offensive and defensive ratings, they are ranked 7th. Therefore, Husker Hoops overperformed and exceeded their ranking.
Shooting the ball, and making those 3-point shots make or break your stats and ranking.


Code
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data=bothsides, aes(x=`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`), color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=nu2, aes(x=`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`), color="#E41C38") +
  geom_point(data=pu, aes(x=`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`), color="#C28E0E") +
  geom_point(data=msu, aes(x=`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`), color="#18453B") +
  geom_point(data=nw, aes(x=`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`), color="#4E2A84") +
  geom_point(data=mi, aes(x=`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`), color="#00274C") +
    geom_vline(xintercept = .3387127, color="lightblue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = .335663, color="lightblue") +
  geom_text_repel(data=nu2, aes(`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`, label=School)) +
  geom_text_repel(data=pu, aes(`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`, label=School)) +
  geom_text_repel(data=nw, aes(`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`, label=School)) +
  geom_text_repel(data=mi, aes(`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`, label=School)) +
  geom_text_repel(data=msu, aes(`Opponent3P%`, y=`Team3P%`, label=School)) +
   labs(
    x="Opponent 3P%", 
    y="Team 3P%", 
    title="Making 3-point shots help", 
    subtitle="Husker Hoops falls short to the opponents 3-point percentage.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









It is hard to win games if other teams shoot better than you. Nebraska shot a lot of 3s and made a lot of 3s, but because they shot so many, their 3-point percentage suffered. Purdue, Northwestern, Michigan, and Michigan State were the four schools with a higher 3-point percentage than Nebraska. Once again, Nebraska exceeded its ranking, as they were ranked 5th with their 3-point percentage.
Turnovers are one of the most painful errors in basketball. It is an error that will change a game for the worst and completely change a teams season.


Code
ggplot() +
geom_bar(data=bigtenbasketball, aes(x=reorder(School,TeamTOV), weight=TeamTOV),fill="lightgrey") +
geom_bar(data=nu, aes(x=reorder(School,TeamTOV), weight=TeamTOV),fill="#E41C38") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Total Turnovers", 
    title="Husker's Preach Ball Security", 
    subtitle="Nebraska continues to over-perform and exceed their ranking.", 
    caption="Source: Sports Reference | By Sophie Widman"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Nebraska is once again in the middle of the pack. According to their total turnovers, they are ranked 7th with 377 turnovers. Once again, the Huskers exceeded their ranking.
2024 was an excellent year for Nebraska Basketball. They had one of the best teams in years. With that being said, in conclusion, Husker Hoops did, in fact, exceed their ranking.
